diff_hunk:
@@ -617,10 +617,10 @@ $ bazel build -c opt //tensorflow/tools/pip_package:build_pip_package
 # To build with GPU support:
 $ bazel build -c opt --config=cuda //tensorflow/tools/pip_package:build_pip_package
 
-$ bazel-bin/tensorflow/tools/pip_package/build_pip_package /tmp/tensorflow_pkg
+$ sudo bazel-bin/tensorflow/tools/pip_package/build_pip_package /tmp/tensorflow_pkg
 
 # The name of the .whl file will depend on your platform.
-$ pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl
+$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl
body:
>  # The name of the .whl file will depend on your platform.
> -$ pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl
> +$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl

Sure it is depend on the platform, In case of OS X, the pip and python
installation need to sudo permission.
In this reason, using OS X enviroment, the pip install description on "
os_setup.md", almost add sudo command.
This commit is just add sudo command on OS X. I do same install from source
code on Ubuntu 14.04. it is not use sudo permission.

wrote:

> > +$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl
> 
> We can make it more explicit that the name depends on the platform, maybe
> in the text below? We can also add a note there that depending on your pip
> and python installation, you may need to use sudo on this command. I'm a

body_html:
The name of the .whl file will depend on your platform.

-$ pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl
+$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl

Sure it is depend on the platform, In case of OS X, the pip and python
installation need to sudo permission.
In this reason, using OS X enviroment, the pip install description on "
os_setup.md", almost add sudo command.
This commit is just add sudo command on OS X. I do same install from source
code on Ubuntu 14.04. it is not use sudo permission.

On Tue, Apr 26, 2016 at 8:17 AM, Martin Wicke notifications@github.com
wrote:

In tensorflow/g3doc/get_started/os_setup.md
#2095 (comment):

The name of the .whl file will depend on your platform.

-$ pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-linux_x86_64.whl
+$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl

We can make it more explicit that the name depends on the platform, maybe
in the text below? We can also add a note there that depending on your pip
and python installation, you may need to use sudo on this command. I'm a
little wary about adding it for everybody, it really shouldn't be required.

—

+$ sudo pip install /tmp/tensorflow_pkg/tensorflow-0.8.0-py2-none-any.whl

Sure it is depend on the platform, In case of OS X, the pip and python
installation need to sudo permission.
In this reason, using OS X enviroment, the pip install description on "
os_setup.md", almost add sudo command.
